prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. Add $1_3 + 12_3 + 212_3 + 2121_3.$ Express your answer in base 3.
solution:
We may sum in base 3 just as in base 10. For example, in the rightmost column, the digits sum to 6. Since we are working in base 3, we record the remainder 0 as the rightmost digit in the sum and carry the quotient 2 to the next column. Continuing in this way, we find $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & 2 & 1 & 2 & 1_3 \\
& & & 2 & 1 & 2_3 \\
& & & & 1 & 2_3 \\
& + & & & & 1_3 \\
\cline{2-6}
& 1 & 0 & 2 & 0 & 0_3, \\
\end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{10200_3}$.
gpt_response:
First, let's add the numbers vertically, starting with the rightmost digit:

\[
\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & 1_3 & & \\
&+ & 1_3 & 2 & \\
&+ & 2_3 & 1 & 2 \\
&+ & 2_3 & 1 & 2 & 1 \\
\cline{1-5}
& & 1_3 & 3 & 0 & 1 \\
\end{array}
\]

So, $1_3 + 12_3 + 212_3 + 2121_3$ equals $1301_3$.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 10200_3?: First, let's add the numbers vertically, starting with the rightmost digit:

\[
\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & 1_3 & & \\
&+ & 1_3 & 2 & \\
&+ & 2_3 & 1 & 2 \\
&+ & 2_3 & 1 & 2 & 1 \\
\cline{1-5}
& & 1_3 & 3 & 0 & 1 \\
\end{array}
\]

So, $1_3 + 12_3 + 212_3 + 2121_3$ equals $1301_3$.
